reviewText:
I played this game on mobile along with BTD5 on mobile. This version is basically identical to the mobile version aside from some additions yet to be implemented.
Pros:
-Clean Graphics
-Great Soundtrack
-Great TD Tower Scheme
-Assault/Defence Modes (One for competitive and casual)
-Win/Loss Ratio & Win %
-Free to play
-P2W Mechanics But Not A P2W Game (Money spending is not needed it just helps. Gives no real dramatic advantage)
Neutral:
-No chat (No communication with opponent but prevents toxic chat messages)
-Somewhat grind intensive
Cons:
-Lag (Lag spikes can become really annoying)
-Random Crashes (Only have had 1 crash so far)
-Hackers (This is the only con that really ruins the game)
I have been a fan of this series for a while, so my bias is in favor of this game. While I feel they addressed this game very well I will address some topics that may want to be heard about.
Grinding:
While, yes, this game requires a decent amount of grinding to get all the towers (Paying for them just unlocks them quicker) the time grinding gives the player a sense of enjoyment of progressing through the ranks of all of the towers and also allows the player to learn at a controlled pace without overdoseing on all the tower upgrades.
Lag/Crashes:
Not much to say here. Some random lag spikes that really don't affect the game that much are just annoying more than a hinderence. Crahses are rare, but do need to be fixed.
Hackers:
Oh boy here we go. Now this is something BTD Battles has always had a problem with. Hackers will cause themselves to become invincible to your attacks which will then cause you to instantly lose unless they lag out. To try to combat this there is a report player" button. However Ninja Kiwi should really try to put a stop to hacking if there is any possible way.
Overall a well structured game. Rating: 8.5/10"

reviewText:
Great game, no pay to win aspect. But... this game isn't all about skill, the progression system is pretty definitely supporting the more experienced. (I got a lot of hate for the next statement, so I have augmented it just for you keyboard warriors.) It takes a bit of time to unlock all the towers, but the addition of arenas and rankings made getting medals easier than before. Every week you get a guaranteed 1k medals if you played at least one game, if you played actively it can scale up to 2k or more. The arenas also help getting medals if you're good, you basically stake the selected value and the winner takes all.

Now of course most towers will have most of the potential unlocked by the time 3 line of upgrades are unlocked and that is relatively cheap compared to fully maxing out (all 4 lines). Here's a good example, the regular monkey is the best started tower in the game, but only if you have the 3rd line of upgrades unlocked, of course it is also the cheapest tower, since in the late game even upgraded to 4th line upgrade it is very bad. It costs around 30 medals to unlock the 3rd line and you get 5 or 7 medals every game that you win (depending on how many lives you had at the time of winning).

The games are relatively fast (5-10min), but sometimes can take up much longer, so they could be compared to the lenght of hearthstone matches. The game is very simple to get into, but has a lot of strategical depth, since when you are in game, nothing is relying on luck, all of it is skill. Oh and (just like a deck builder) you can only pick 3 towers that you take into the battlefield, with an optional 4th one (in regular mode you can roll it for 1 energy (you have 20 max and it restores at a rate of 1 energy per 5 min, you can't buy more energy) and in arena mode you get a free roll and a free re-roll).

The game is a lot of fun when you unlock some towers, I have played it very long on the phone and it was very easy to sync my progress with the pc. I truly recommend this game to anyone who likes strategy without RNG.

reviewText:
This easy butter chicken recipe can be made in 35 minutes and is SUPER delicious. It's rich, creamy and addictive. It's also very easy to make dairy-free!



Makes: 4 servings


Ingredients
2 tablespoons grapeseed oil (or another neutral flavoured oil)
1 lb. chicken breast or tenders (see notes)
2 yellow onions, roughly chopped
3 tablespoons chopped ginger
6 garlic cloves, crushed
1 tablespoon garam masala
1 teaspoon ground turmeric
1 teaspoon coriander, ground or seeds
1 teaspoon cumin, ground or seeds
¼ teaspoon fenugreek, ground or seeds
¼ to 1 teaspoon chili powder
Seeds from 4 cardamom pods
1 - 28-ounce can of crushed or diced tomatoes
2 tablespoons almond butter
2 tablespoons dairy or coconut cream
2-4 tablespoons brown sugar, to taste
Optional: 2 tablespoons plain yogurt
Sea salt, to taste (I like about 2 teaspoons)

1.Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a medium-sized frying pan over medium-high heat. Add the chicken breasts or tenders and cook, stirring frequently, until they are cooked through and no longer pink, about 12-15 minutes. Remove them from the pan and cut them into 1-inch chunks.

2.While the chicken is cooking begin preparing the sauce. Add the remaining tablespoon of oil to a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until the onion starts to brown, about 10 minutes. Add the garlic and ginger and cook for 1 minute more.

3.Add all the spices all at once, or remove the pan from the heat for a moment while you add them. (garam masala, turmeric, coriander, cumin, fenugreek, chili powder and cardamom seeds) Let the spices cook for about one minute, or until they are quite fragrant. Add the tomatoes to the pan and scrape up any stuck on brown bits. Add half a cup of water and bring the pot to a boil. Lower the heat to medium and let the sauce simmer for 15 minutes.

4.Carefully add the sauce to your blender and blend on high until it is very smooth. Add the sauce back to the pan and stir through the almond butter, dairy or coconut cream and the optional yoghurt.

5.Serve with a side of rice.

reviewText:
While the game is super fun to play, it's very unlikely that you will play it for more than 15 minutes per session without having to spend money.

If you're new to the game or starting fresh in the Steam version you'll soon realize that you will easily lose in the dumbest ways simply because either your opponent is a much higher level than you or because they have all of the good building unlocked. Since this is the case you are constantly having to use Dart Monkeys for camo baloons, Boomerang Monkeys for lead baloons, and using all of your energy to re-roll in vein that you either get a Bloonchipper, Cobra (which is easily the most broken thing about the game), or Monkey Sub. Either you can take days if not weeks to unlock them, while still needing medals to unlock all of their abilities, or you can buy each building for $4.99 each which is absurd. Once you run out of the initial 20 energy (which it takes 3 to roll each time) than you have to wait for it to regenerate. One energy takes 5 real-time minutes to come back so you often find yourself playing two matches, running out of energy, and turning the game off because you don't want to have to pay money for more.

You have to get medals in order to unlock new buildings but you don't get any if you lose the match, which I've noticed that most players have a 60% winning streak or lower, so if you're like me and your winning streak is 50%, that means that half of the matches you've played were useless and just a waste of time because you got nothing for them.
There is no ranked matching in the game so you will often come across players who have the most advance stuff unlocked at max tier with you only having the basics - so you'll suffer a loss just for getting unlucky which isn't fair. You can also buy the medals with money too.

Pros:
• Fun Gameplay

Cons:
• No Balancing
• Noob-Unfriendly
• Full of Microtransactions, which are pretty pricey
• Only fun in short bursts
• Too long and hard to unlock tower tiers without paying for them

Verdict:
While the game is fun and addicting it is very limiting unless you either wait for your energy to refill or spend money in a game that should have been $4.99 - $9.99 to begin with. If the pay-to-win aspect of the game wasn't such a problem than I would highly recommend this game but in it's current form I don't think it's worth your time. 5.6/10

Stick to Bloons TD5 until they come out with a full version of this game.

reviewText:
Product received for free

good take on the Bloons franchise... except for the tons of poor UI limitations.
- no replay function (you can't see what you did wrong or what your opponent did right).
- lack of keybinds for sending balloons (the available keybinds are not even shown in-game)
- poor use of screen real estate (probably because there's some mobile version)
- tower descriptions often give insufficient info (price, attack speed, range, damage... all mostly missing)
- bloon descriptions are pretty much completely missing in game
- tower placement is still dependent on skillful mouse-pixelling; no snap-to-edge function
- some towers require unnecessary micro: farms, gatling, etc
- tower abilities don't allow targeting (and also have no keybinds)
- incoming waves are neither described nor indicated

some gameplay elements are also not up to par for a multiplayer game:
- no elo matching (it's pretty much a random matchup)
- weirdly structured leaderboards (no way for newcomers to catch up without weeks of grind)
- medal pricing is quite prohibitive for newcomers (be prepared to grind the first few days unless you git gud fast)
- towers aren't very balanced (apprentice/ninja/buccaneer > almost every other tower)

all in all, if you enjoyed the bloon TD games, this is a pretty fun take allowing you to match against other players. at the very least, the game isn't P2W. well, you could pay to unlock towers more quickly, and that COULD help you win; but it only takes at most up until your first weekly reward to unlock most towers.

nonetheless, until they upgrade the UI substantially, this game will annoy the heck out of you and force you to read copious amounts of guides just to find out what towers do, which bloons to send when, and why certain waves + assault are so powerful. if you just want a casual versus game, might wanna look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Good concept - ruined by the freemium/pay to win/an evil dragon is holding my daughter to ransom in a cave and will only accept microtransactions to pay for her release... model.

The VS mode is an good addition to Bloons TD compared to previous attempts at multiplayer which have been pretty pointless, it’s just a shame they decided to lock off all the fun by a grind long enough to slay an actual dragon. The points and level needed to unlock towers are awarded at a terminally slow rate and even after winning my first 4 games I wasn’t really coming close to buying any of the towers my opponents had been using against me... let along upgrading them.

Of course if money is no concept for you at all... say if you’ve had all your vital organs replaced by advanced circuitry and no longer require food then you could just buy everything and skip the wait. That would cost £82.78. Yes... I actually added it up just to see how absurd of a figure it would invariably be. The payments don’t stop there either... there’s energy for boosts/unfair advantages, 100,000 ‘medallions’ for the low, low sum of another eighty quid, some kind of energy regenerator and even a way to pay to reset your stats. Frankly after all that it seems pretty bold to put a link to the merchandise shop in there...

Definitely sounds like the work of a greedy dragon to me. I look forward to seeing what new and exciting ways of wasting your money this game introduces with each update.

Besides from putting a dent in your wallet more effectively than a fiscally orientated rhinoceros with a freshly sharpened horn and a fondness for headbutting this model simply destroys any sense of competitive play. I won my first two or three games as it was clear the other players were also new and they were genuinely fun. The assault mode more so than the defensive but both had their merits. During the next game though the other player had upgraded dartling guns so I figured I was just about done for.

Fortunately though it seemed he hadn’t quite worked out which end the darts came out of and which end had a face and a tail (there’s an odd sentence) so he had them pointing in the wrong direction half the time. It also didn’t seem to occur to him to actually send any bloons against me so I somehow won that too. In reality that defence should have been unbeatable though. Next I was thrown into a game against someone who both knew what they were doing and had spent an enormous amount of time playing (or an enormous amount of money) as they had fully upgraded versions of all the most expensive towers. Literally all they had to do was sit back and watch me die to the inevitably overpowering waves that no starting towers alone could possibly beat.

Even in a balanced game it seems the ‘sending bloons against your enemy’ thing usually just seems to serve as an investment to increase your income as every win or loss I had came down to the level eventually getting too hard rather than the actions of either player. I frankly could not imagine playing enough games of this to unlock my preferred towers because it gets boring quite easily - far more so than previous bloons. Also if I did unlock all the stuff I wanted... what would be the point? If I am then just going to be the one playing against new people who have no chance then what fun is there in that?

Essentially then this is a game which gives you two options:

A. Choose the grind and get about 50% reasonably fun, balanced games and 50% which you cannot possibly win because your opponent has all the upgrades.

or

B. Take out a high interest loan against your possessions and spend a few months absolutely demolishing the new players the game has matched you with whilst maniacally cackling... until the bank repossess your computer.

I could say it needs a better matchmaking system, new maps and rebalancing of some of the towers which were already ludicrously overpowered in Bloons 5 but in reality it just needs to go away before money grabbing games like this do to Steam what they did to mobile gaming...

I say just let the dragon eat the little ♥♥♥♥♥.

Next I was thrown into a game against someone who both knew what they were doing and had spent an enormous amount of time playing (or an enormous amount of money) as they had fully upgraded versions of all the most expensive towers. Literally all they had to do was sit back and watch me die to the inevitably overpowering waves that no starting towers alone could possibly beat.

Even in a balanced game it seems the ‘sending bloons against your enemy’ thing usually just seems to serve as an investment to increase your income as every win or loss I had came down to the level eventually getting too hard rather than the actions of either player. I frankly could not imagine playing enough games of this to unlock my preferred towers because it gets boring quite easily - far more so than previous bloons. Also if I did unlock all the stuff I wanted... what would be the point? If I am then just going to be the one playing against new people who have no chance then what fun is there in that?

Essentially then this is a game which gives you two options:

A. Choose the grind and get about 50% reasonably fun, balanced games and 50% which you cannot possibly win because your opponent has all the upgrades.

or

B. Take out a high interest loan against your possessions and spend a few months absolutely demolishing the new players the game has matched you with whilst maniacally cackling... until the bank repossess your computer.

I could say it needs a better matchmaking system, new maps and rebalancing of some of the towers which were already ludicrously overpowered in Bloons 5 but in reality it just needs to go away before money grabbing games like this do to Steam what they did to mobile gaming...

TL;DR: Bloons is a fun tower defense with multiple game modes and a varied amount of towers that I recommend played on the toiler (phone) and not on steam (PC... go play something with more depth!)

Bloons TD Battles is a port from your phone over to PC.  You can tell this immediately by the fact there is no way to turn down the volume after it deafens your ears.  You can either completely mute the volume or leave it on the default game setting.  You can either leave the game in full screen or a predetermined resolution windowed mode.

Outside of these poor options, Bloons is a really good tower defense.  Like all pay to win models, it suffers from having a ton of content that is restricted by a massive time investment or moderate (to massive) cash investment.  At the time of this review, I have 10 towers unlocked by can only use a maximum of 4 at a time.  Which allows me to use the wizard and any other random 3 because the wizard is OP in the early game.

There are random draft clubs you can play once, then can pay money to join later on.  In game currency can be wagered at predetermined amounts in best of 1 matches.

I recommend the game, but not on PC.  Play something with a little more depth on PC and play this game while your boss isn't looking at work.

reviewText:
I have always been a BTD fan, I have been around the community for years and I wish to clear ALL the misconceptions.
Flash>Steam>Mobile
8/10

To begin, I notice that many, many negative reviews are on this game, 90% of these people have not played anymore than 1hr of the game, which frustrates me as it does not give a correct view of the game, for example if you play DOTA 2, and lose your first game and then make a bad review you have not experienced the game, as the game is far more complex than most people believe. Anyway back to BTD.

- BTD battles steam is literally a carbon copy of the mobile version with the addition of SOME hotkeys which level the playing field between mobile and PC. Although being a steam game, it has very limited settings which may annoy some more techy people such as myself, but it is bearable.
- Secondly, the 'pay-2-win' element of the game which countless negative reviews are complaining about is a very minor part of the game, as not only is the matchmaking fairly accurate but the grind to obtain these tower upgrades is very small, only taking about 10-20hrs to get EVERYTHING, comparing that to warframe where you need to put in a minimum of about 300+hrs in.
- Next, is the skill based area, this is the part which frustrates me the most, DO NOT EXPECT TO WIN IF YOU HAVE JUST STARTED, it is just like a MOBA, you are gonna lose a lot in the beginning until you learn the strategies and the physics behind the game, I was the same. Although balancing is a major issue in the game, it is not a problem as 90% of the time you will be matched with someone of equal skill level, and an equal amount of stuff unlocked.
- Fourth, is a simple one, there is no exit button. All you need to do is go to settings and change it to windowed mode, this allows you to fullscreen it with a border that has an exit button
- Fifth, this is another thing that really annoys me. Many people complain about losing to rushes, it is part of the game, you are playing on 'ASSAULT' mode for a reason, if you prefer late game, play defense, and yes defense is hard to learn but once you learn it, you can go late game every game. The concept is not that hard
- lastly, many people say that people put a lot of money in, you can transfer your data from the mobile version meaning people who have played 10,000 games can move to steam so, most likely they did not pay, and yes there are some people out there who do pay, but you most likely only be paired up with them if there is no one else available.

Now the comparison of the steam/mobile version to the flash version. The flash version has been forgotten by 90% of BTD players and for the more competitive game, it is the superior version. BTD battles flash, although worse graphics, less community, and no arenas, is a wonderful game, that boasts its amazing balance and physics which make the game a much more serious version compared to the mobile version. This is not suggesting which one is better because the mobile/steam version is targeted to the more general casual audience who just enjoys playing, thus the reason i am giving it 8/10 and not 6/10 because it is not targeted at the more competitive players.

however it also has a premium version too, aka club access/membership, this is bought through an in-app purchase of the Unlimited Club Access (which is a once off payment, permanantly offering access to the premium content that is otherwise only accessible [if at all] once every 24 hours).

If you're someone who doesn't like paying for stuff in f2p games simply because you know that they charge way too much for what you get and would be more willing to pay if the game acted more like a regular pay to play title... then this game in my opinion has the best of both worlds.
